column5: Originally used with the genitive case in older Loremese.
When used as a unit of measurement, it is equal to approx. 28.69 liters or 28.69 kilograms.
The meaning “fruit” is restricted to compounds and overly careless colloquial speech.

column6: Ecascarva refers specifically to coffee fruits grown in Azkali, or styles of coffee that are characteric of or traditional in Azkali. The general terms for coffee fruit and coffee are veiçinia and veiçiniata respectively.

column5: Widespread non-standard spellings include Bafia and Babia.
Widespread non-standard spellings include bafico and babico.
This word is used to refer to things pertaining to both the Bellic Ocean in general and the Union of the Bellic Islands specifically.
When used as a unit of measurement, it is equal to approx. 2.869 liters or 2.869 kilograms.
Colloquial. May also be spelled sagio.
Loremese uses the -yllion system for big numbers.
When used as a unit of measurement, it is equal to approx. 286.9 milliliters or 286.9 grams.

Me is used for prohibitions, i.e. negatived imperatives, instead of noic.
Spele ia! “Say that!” → Me spele ia! “Don’t say that!”
When used as a unit of measurement, it is equal to approx. 2.869 milliliters or 2.869 grams.

In Saulism, sa Gouti refers to the 20-day period from the day after Zerilo’s Day to New Year’s Eve, specifically. When used to refer to fasting periods in other religions, the word is not capitalised.
Associated with the Silly Season, especially Zerilo’s Day.
When used as a unit of measurement, it is equal to approx. 30.61 centimeters.

Marks future tense with a present tense verb and conditional mood with a perfect tense verb:
So zau azetor. “It will be done.”
Tu noic zau enems na anat. “You would not take a duck.”
While literally meaning “good morning”, this phrase is used at all times of day as a generic greeting and farewell.
Eschewed by non-Saulists due to its etymological connection to saul “sun”.
Also colloquially spelled as Ihoçhar.
Also colloquially spelled as ihoçharico.
This verb is used in the sense of “know a fact”. For the sense “to be acquainted with”, see zloço.
This verb is used in the sense of “to be acquainted with”. For the sense “know a fact”, see deio.
When used as a unit of measurement, it is equal to approx. 3.061 millimeters.
Loremese uses the -yllion system for big numbers.
Loremese uses the -yllion system for big numbers.
Used to negate statements and questions. For negative imperatives, see me “don’t”.

Loremese uses the -yllion system for big numbers.
When used as a unit of measurement, it is equal to approx. 3.061 meters.

Adherents of Shidamism prefer the spelling Çhidama.

Adherents of Shidamism prefer the spelling çhidamimo.
This word is used exclusively for true tea. For tea-like drinks such as herbal or fruit teas, use vrita “tisane” instead.
Azetor is placed at the end of the phrase.

Loremese ordinarily uses the -yllion system for big numbers. Zelo is only used instead of deçat çato (lit. “ten hundred”) when the number of hundreds is divisible by ten, e.g. 2000 = dvos zelo “two thousand”, but 2100 = dviçont oino çato “twenty-one hundred”.
When used as a unit of measurement, it is equal to approx. 3.061 centimeters, 28.69 milliliters or 28.69 grams.
This word is used for tea-like drinks extracted from dried herbs or fruit. For proper tea, see gosdiata.
When used as a unit of measurement, it is equal to approx. 30.61 meters.
The word is plural only. The singular forms are not used.
Loremese uses the -yllion system for big numbers.
Colloquially also called Semoti “Union”.
Widespread non-standard spellings include Iamahat and Iamaat.
Widespread non-standard spellings include iamahatico and iamaatico.
